Aranda has seen his profile jump so much::: heâ€™s been mentioned as a possible candidate at Southern Cal to replace Clay Helton. As Bruce Feldman of The Athletic points out::: â€œWhen USC fired Clay Helton::: Dave Aranda had a career record of 4-7. In the 2 months since::: heâ€™s led Baylor to an 8-2 record and now his coaching stock is soaring.â€ Aranda is getting more attention because the Baylor defense bottled up Oklahoma to its fewest yards (260) since 2014 as the game served as a perfect showcase for Aranda and his program. Arandaâ€™s Bears were 2-7 in 2020 in his first season::: but have improved to 6-1 this season. Aranda was also the defensive coordinator for LSU from 2016 through the 2019 season::: when the Tigers won a national championship. After the 2019 season::: Aranda left to take the head coaching job at Baylor. Arandaâ€™s name has also come up in relation to LSU. About 3 weeks ago::: Aranda responded to being mentioned for possible openings. â€œI love it here:::â€ Aranda said. â€œMy family loves it here. Baylor has been everything that I thought it would be. column10: I will never forget::: one day I was walking to class through Founder's Mall when I came upon a squirrel who was not the least bit afraid of me. I was surprised by how close he let me get to him. I knelt down and extended my arm. He came up and sniffed my fingers::: then he bit me and ran away. Another student walked up behind me and said::: "Oh my gosh::: did you just feed that squirrel by hand?" I said::: "No::: he bit me." It didn't hurt::: he thought I was offering him.a nut.

column3: I was a student at Baylor on 9-11-01. I watched the events of that morning unfold in real time along side some of my classmates and professors. Like many classes the rest of the week::: the football game was cancelled::: but the first game back was unlike anything else. As a member of BUGWB::: we prepared a special show. During pre-game::: we played the National Anthem like we had at every home game before::: but this time was different. The crowd sang with us::: not a dull hum like previous games::: but really sang::: every word clear with so much passion and pride. I couldnâ€™t play my part::: I just stood there and wept.

column9: The morning of 9/ 11::: I swam laps with a friend in the (then new) SLC and then we did a lap around the Bear Trail. It was a most beautiful morning. It was the beginning of my last semester. I was graduating that December. We talked about our futures post-graduation as we jogged. As I drove back to my apartment::: I heard that a small plane hit the WTC on the local radio station. I went inside my apartment and turned on the television and saw the second tower hit. On my sofa say law school brochures for NYU (with a map showing the school's proximity to the WTC and other NYC landmarks)::: Georgetown and Harvard. I cried and called my parents. Shortly after a group of Baylor students living in the complex came together to pray in the lawn between our buildings. We were all stunned. Most of us then went to our classes. I had negotiations class in the business school. I remember our teacher tried to focus on the lesson but none of us were into it. On my way home that day::: I waited in line to get gas on LaSalle because we were told there could be shortages. That day is forever seared in all of our memories and changed us. A year later I started law school at Harvard. I was so thankful I got in because immediately post-9/11::: I don't think I would have moved to DC or NYC. Of all my 9/11 memories::: the peaceful::: beautiful morning on the Baylor campus is one of the strongest. I guess it was the last day of true innocence for so many of us.

With classes starting one week from today::: a question:  What one piece of advice would you share with Baylor freshmen on their first day of college?
column3: You're going to meet the best friends you'll ever have so relish the experiences. Have stories to tell when you're old. You won't remember any grades that you make but you'll remember the people and the stories. You have the rest of your life to be an adult.
column4: 1) Have someone take a first day of school picture of you. Your mom will love you even more for it. 2) Give yourself grace. 3) Get vaccinated. 4) Remember that youâ€™re at school to learn. But have fun too! Youâ€™ll find your balance.
column5: Know you are not alone there are other freshman going through the same thing and God to help you. I am excited for each and every one of you::: get ready to make lifelong friends.
column6: Take advantage of EVERYTHING! Don't miss a lecture series::: a game::: a chapel::: a "Dr. Pepper Hour:::" a play or a concert. Naps are SO overrated.
column7: Breathe. Take everything in bite-sized pieces. Always just do the very next best thing â€” and then do the next â€” and so on. And when you lose::: don't lose the lesson.  Oh... and have a blast. You are a very fortunate person to be a Baylor Bear. It's a gift. Treasure it. Share it.

column35: My Dad::: Baylor Class of 1958::: a college professor for over 30 years wrote out these words of wisdom for his first grandson off to college this year. This is good stuff for everyone: Tomorrow begins a new chapter in your life. Last week was just getting ready- tomorrow is for real. I have prayed for this day a long time. You are prepared because of your loving family- particularly parents. As you start the rest of your life::: remember who you are::: where you came from and what lies ahead. You will be a success in college as well as later in life. We are all very proud of you- don't let us down. You soon will experience things that will require intelligent decisions. Make these decisions the right decisions. AND- some important things regarding actual classroom "stuff": 1. Be on time for class- There is NO EXCUSE for being late. 2. Sit on the front row. 3. Call you professor by his/her proper title- Mr::: Mrs::: or Dr.- some professors will say titles are not important- NOT TRUE! Call them Dr if they hold the title- they've worked very hard to earn that right by years and years of study often with great sacrifice. 3. Never converse with classmates when class is in session. You are there to learn. Respect your professor. 4. Be prepared for class. Turn in assignments pronto- you will know when things are due- remember- no excuses. Good teachers won't accept late work anyway. 5. Dress sharp for class and have good hygiene. Professors hate sloppy looking students. 6. NEVER::: NEVER ::: NEVER wear a cap in class- NEVER! Even if the professor says it it ok. 7. Always be courteous- to everybody. 8. Don't be the class clown 9. Anything else that I forgot to mention. 10. Don't ever look at your cell phone in class unless your professor directs you to. Keep it on silent or leave it in your room! 11. Remember to call or text your parents. They have worked hard to get you here - they want to hear from you. You may not miss them::: but they miss you! Remember that I spent almost all my working life in higher education and experienced tons of stuff- I can help::: call on me!

Baylor Football is back on the practice field -- which means the new school year must be right around the corner. ğŸ»ğŸˆ  Just 10 days 'til classes start! ğŸ‘€

Like many universities::: the recent spread of COVID-19 locally & statewide has prompted us to update our COVID-related protocols for the fall.  The goal: Safely offering a full Baylor experience (in-person classes::: full student activities::: etc.) this semester.  We continue to strongly encourage all students::: faculty & staff to get vaccinated as soon as possible. Free appointments are available on campus. (Already vaccinated? Let us know.) To find an appointment and/or report your vaccination::: visit baylor.edu/vaccine.  Faculty/staff & students who are unvaccinated (and who have not tested positive for COVID-19 within the past 180 days) will be tested twice weekly for at least the first four weeks of the semester. This will help us identify and respond to any potential outbreaks on campus.  In certain indoor settings::: face coverings will now be required on a temporary basis. This includes all classrooms & labs::: as well as some other indoor locations where appropriate social distancing may not be possible.  With local housing & hotel room availability limited::: each student should have a plan in case he/she is required to isolate or quarantine due to a COVID exposure or positive test.  These plans are subject to change if local conditions improve (or deteriorate) through the first month of the fall semester. Thank you for adhering to these important COVID protocols as we work to keep both our campus and our local community as healthy as possible. #SicCOVID  Complete details:  BAYLOR.EDU eNews: Updated Fall COVID-19 protocols

Baylor continues to work through the recovery phase of COVID-19 and prepare for a normal fall semester. President Livingstone's weekly email today offers an update on campus plans::: based on the most current information we have about the virus.  Highlights: Baylor will be at 100% capacity indoors and outdoors. (This includes all campus facilities and athletic venues such as McLane Stadium and the Ferrell Center.) We will return to our in-person instructional model::: with no special social distancing in classrooms.  We will also return to normal::: in-person student experiences::: including campus events::: in-person student organization meetings::: the Baylor Line run & sporting events::: and in-person traditions such as Family Weekend::: Homecoming::: and Sing.  Our Student Life team is also planning unique opportunities specifically for rising sophomores (#BU24). More information on these plans will be shared this fall.  Masks/face coverings are no longer required on campus (effective today). However::: we do recommend that those who are unvaccinated wear a face covering indoors::: as well as individuals working within labs and other settings that require this level of protection.  We plan weekly COVID-19 testing for unvaccinated students & faculty/staff for at least the first 4 weeks of the fall. If::: as anticipated::: we have a great start to the fall semester::: we will revisit the testing policy early in the semester and adjust as needed.  Baylor will not require COVID vaccinations for attendance this fall. However::: we continue to encourage vaccination. Fully vaccinated students & faculty/staff are asked to let us know at baylor.edu/vaccine in order to be exempted from weekly testing & quarantine.  "We will continue to keep you updated::: but please know that as much as I look forward to your return to campus::: my prayers are with you for a healthy summer -\-\ physically::: mentally and spiritually." -\-\ President Livingstone  BAYLOR.EDU Presidential Perspective - July 1::: 2021

column1: At their annual May meeting::: Baylor's Board of Regents approved phase one of a capital projects plan::: heard updates on historical campus master planning::: approved guiding principles for caring for all students (including LGBTQ students)::: & more: https://bit.ly/3flBZQM  The Board approved construction to begin this summer on the Mark & Paula Hurd Welcome Center::: with completion targeted for May 2023. Part of the Hurd Welcome Center will be the newly named McLane Family Alumni Center::: in honor of Drayton McLane Jr. & family.  The Board also approved resuming renovations on residence halls::: with Collins (in 2022-23) and Memorial & Alexander (2023-24) halls following previous years' work on Russell::: Penland & Martin::: and the operating budget for 2021-22.  Following the Commission on Historic Campus Representations' work::: Baylor has secured Sasaki::: a renowned architecture::: planning::: landscape & design firm::: to assist in historical master planning as the university evaluates & implements the Commission's recommendations.  Recognizing the need to care for all Bears -\-\ including LGBTQ students -\-\ while following traditional Scriptural teaching on sexuality::: the Board urged university leaders to find appropriate ways to better serve LGBTQ students::: including possibly establishing a new chartered student group.  The Board also: * celebrated Paula Hurd's $7 million gift & #GiveLightBU passing the $1 billion mark; * approved Board leadership & new members for 2021-22; * heard updates on a long-term student faith & character formation study::: & a recent faculty job satisfaction survey.  BAYLOR.EDU Baylor Regents Approve Construction of Mark and Paula Hurd Welcome Center::: Celebrate $1 Billion Milestone for Give Light Campaign

Our thoughts & prayers are with the friends & family of two Baylor professors following their passing this week.  Dr. Jerry Johnson (BBA â€™62::: MBA â€™65) died Tuesday after a lengthy illness. Johnson was a longtime fixture in the Hankamer School of Business::: teaching marketing from 1974 until his retirement earlier this year. He was also known to countless fans as the voice of the Golden Wave Band::: announcing half-time shows for 46 years: https://bit.ly/3eqIwKM  Dr. Scott James passed away suddenly earlier this week while visiting family in California. He came to Baylor in 2014 as a geosciences professor after a career in private industry and at several U.S. national labs. A prolific research scholar::: James had earned tenure just last summer. Baylor will host a service of remembrance and conversation this afternoon in Ellison Chapel: https://bit.ly/3b8pEhj

column12: Honest question::: if the positive rate among students consistently has hovered well under 1% in spite of the fact that most students are completely intermingling/ socializing ::: than why on earth can they not participate normally at this time? They are already::: and have been for months::: socializing. Itâ€™s just that itâ€™s not during officially sanctioned activities. That is the absolute truth. Just check social media. Also::: the ICU bed capacity in Waco consistently has hovered around 90% for at least since February when I started to check on a regular basis. There are 29 million people in Texas. As of today there are 2:::500 in the ICU with Covid. The governor lifted the mask/ restrictions March 10. All I am is statin facts. The students are absolutely NOT causing Covid outbreaks. In fact::: and I have this conversation at the hospital where I work::: they have immunity and are probably somewhat protecting their community with this immunity. Itâ€™s just the truth. Covid in Texas is going down because of people who have the antibodies from previous infection and because of the vaccine. Donâ€™t get me wrong::: I love Baylor::: I just value truth. We need to be willing to truthfully look at what is ACTUALLY occurring.

I find it helps.

column1: Last June::: Baylor's Board of Regents acknowledged BU's historical connections to slavery and created a Commission on Historic Campus Representations to offer guidance on telling a fuller history of BU.  Today::: we share the Commission's findings and recommendations: http://bit.ly/BUHistRep  -\-\-\-\-  Among the Commission's key findings that led to their recommendations: Many of Baylor's early leaders (including all three founders) were slaveholders. Some (such as Rufus Burleson) actively supported the Confederacy::: and continued to justify slavery even after 1865.  The Commission's recommendations offer many different options for resolving campus representations of Baylor's history::: with the aim of more fully telling the university's story.  Their recommendations include: * Adding text to existing monuments::: such as the Judge Baylor statue::: to more fully tell the founders' stories * Memorializing the unknown enslaved * Renaming Burleson Quadrangle * Honoring people of color who have contributed to Baylorâ€™s history with statues or other installations * Updating markers at Baylor's original site in Independence::: TX * Telling a more complete history of BU at Line Camp * Retiring/replacing the University Mace  The full::: independent Report of the Commission::: including the historical context and recommendations for each historical representation studied by the group::: is available online at the link below.  One of the first actions to be taken: Statues honoring Baylor's first Black graduates::: Rev. Robert Gilbert (BA â€™67) and Barbara Walker (BA â€™67)::: will be added in front of Tidwell Bible Building::: where they took classes and walked down the street where the Judge Baylor statue is located: http://bit.ly/3fbQBnc  "The resulting actions the Board and University ultimately will take will be guided solely by our Christian mission::: anchored singularly in the Gospelâ€™s pattern for redemption and reconciliation::: and directed at fostering an environment through which racial equality is inextricably linked to our mission and in which students::: faculty::: staff::: alumni and friends of color know they are valued and loved throughout the Baylor community." -\-\ Board Chair Mark Rountree (BBA '86::: MTA '87)  BAYLOR.EDU Commission on Historic Campus Representations

column10: As a Christian::: I think it's important to understand how representations and idolization of slave holders and a culture of slavery is hurtful to people of color who are also children of God and Baylor students::: faculty::: staff::: and alumni. Even if you are not personally offended::: the gravity of the message we send to BIPOC members of the Baylor Family when we want to cling to or celebrate a history entwined with the atrocities of slavery goes well beyond offense. Holding these representations in positions of prominence and esteem is exclusionary::: oppressive::: and racist. I'm proud of the commission who seem to understand the ethos of the Maya Angelou quote::: "Do the best you can until you know better. Then when you know better::: do better." This is Baylor trying to do better::: and for that I'm grateful.

column12: Very sad to read this. While I donâ€™t agree with these founding Fatherâ€™s stances on slavery::: it is part of the world as it was at that point in time. column13: My heart is heavy as I read these misguided recommendations concerning an institution that is not just my alma mater::: but soon that of my child. This is an absolute travesty. It is repulsive that we bend to the voices that drive us to HIDE OUR HISTORY or CHANGE NAMES that brought not just Baylor but the City of Waco and the State of Texas where we are today. Go ahead. Read the rest of the story of Rufus Burleson::: and as you do::: refrain from the narrow::: biased intent of those who made these decisions. Study history. ACTUAL history. Please. Besides serving as Baylorâ€™s president::: this is the man who pastored FBC Waco and baptized Sam Houston. This â€œprogressiveâ€ cancel mentality is detrimental to our impact as the great school that we should be. Of course I am all for supporting all students regardless of color::: race::: background::: etc. But::: we all have a privilege to live in 2021. Not 1865. We also all have a privilege of building a future positively together. That cannot happen by crucifying the heroes of our university and handling them apologetically and speaking of them only with embarrassment. Look at the bigger picture. Slavery was abolished A LONG TIME AGO. Racism is an issue today of course::: but these are not the positive steps we need to take. Begin by separating 21st century racism from 19th century slavery. Then move ahead. Baylor administration and trustees â€” please lead accordingly. #SaveRufusBurles on
column14: It is interesting to note that almost every place I can think of::: now or in the past::: has or had some type of division. It may not be along racial lines as we have experienced predominantly in the US. Rather in other areas::: it might be religious or class based::: evident in regions where everyone is the same race. Another example is a totalitarian regime against its own citizens. It seems that indeed we (humans) are flawed and largely incapable of loving everyone as God does.  While not insensitive to the discussion at hand::: I wonder what we can do to end division now and to help everyone to be able to more fully enjoy this life here on earth and ensure freedom to live a full and meaningful life with freedom from oppression.  Human trafficking::: abortion::: religious persecution::: absolute poverty are sad conditions we are seeing today yet are â€œculturally acceptableâ€ to so many::: just as slavery once was here in the US. While learning from the past::: we might grow determined to stopping such horrendous situations occurring today.

column54: Here are some takeaways of my read through it:  1. This should be just the start. While the report does mention some of the terrible atrocities perpetuated against those enslaved by Baylorâ€™s founders::: Baylorâ€™s press around this has continuously mentioned trying to hold recognizing the horrors of slavery upheld by Baylor's founders with the "good work" they were able to do::: and attempts to couch the work of the commission as â€œredemptive.â€  2. What is missing is an accounting of the true horrors of slavery: rape::: murder::: beatings::: mutilation::: dismemberment::: torture::: to name a few. We know from history that many slaveholders and those in their employ committed these acts::: all of which would have been considered â€œlegal:::â€ and the majority of which would never have been reported.  3. Whatâ€™s also missing is that no enslaved black person::: or black person in general through Jim Crow that was accused of a crime had a fair trial::: and were often murdered on nothing more than hearsay::: so accounts of Judge R.E.B. Baylor issuing rulings that resulted in the execution and lynchings of enslaved persons cannot be taken as acts of justice. Remember that Emmett Till was lynched in 1955 after being falsely accused by Carolyn Bryant of having flirted with her.  4. The history of lynchings in Washington and McLennan Counties is also not mentioned. Between 1877 and 1950::: there were 5 *known* lynchings in Washington County (where Independence is located)::: and 15 in McLennan County (where Waco is located). Given the prominence of those associated with Baylor in both communities::: connections between them are not illogical.  Some notable points from the report:  5. On how slavery was instrumental in Baylorâ€™s founding: "All three of Baylorâ€™s primary founders were slave owners::: 11 of Baylorâ€™s first 15 members of the Board of Trustees were slave owners::: and Baylorâ€™s first four presidents were slave owners."  6. On the executions and lynchings ordered by Judge R.E.B. Baylor:  "In fulfilling his duties as a judge::: Judge Baylor presided over cases that resulted in the punishment of an abolitionist harboring an escaped slave::: the punishment of a man for not returning a borrowed slave promptly::: the sentencing of a slave to hang for arson::: the execution of another slave in 1856::: and the execution of a slave for â€œintent to rape a white female.â€ The slave who was hung for arson::: in which several deaths occurred::: was named Peter. He had been found guilty by the courtâ€”a decision that was upheld by the Texas Supreme Court. Judge Baylor was then left to pronounce judgment; he sentenced Peter to hang on April 28::: 1845. The slave executed for intent to rape a white woman was named George. A jury in Brenham found him guilty::: and Judge Baylor ordered him to be hanged on November 14::: 1862::: during the Civil War.â€  7. Judge R.E.B Baylor on the necessity of â€œcompellingâ€ freed slaves to work post-Civil War:  After the Civil War was over::: Judge Baylor wrote to one of his nephews::: who was considering moving to Texas from Indiana::: that he should bring with him workers and skilled laborers. The reason for this suggestion::: Judge Baylor explained::: was â€œthe indolent habits of the free Negroes. They will not work with a few exceptionsâ€¦. Do not misunderstand me::: I do not mean that the Negro must be a slave again to compel him to work. I simply mean he must be forced to work in some way::: otherwise they will become vagabonds.â€  8. Showcasing a former slave of Judge R.E.B. Baylor at the dedication of his statue in 1939:  "Also participating in the dedication ceremony was Ann Freeman::: one of Judge Baylorâ€™s former slaves::: who was presented on stage to the applause of the audience."  9. The repeated rape of Antonia Teixeria::: a 14-year-old Brazilian missionary student who lived in the home of Rufus Burleson and was repeatedly raped there by his son-in-law H. Steen Morris:  â€œIssues regarding the treatment of Antonia Teixeira::: a young woman entrusted to the care of the Burleson family during Rufus Burlesonâ€™s presidency whose rape and the controversy surrounding the related criminal case contributed to Burlesonâ€™s retirement as Baylor president in 1897.â€  10. Baylor Founder James Huckins abuse of a woman he enslaved:  â€œIn addition::: one member of his church in Galveston issued an objection against his ministry in 1844 after allegedly hearing Huckins physically beating a female slave inside his house.â€  This is a reminder that is is only a fraction of the untold history of racial violence and terror experienced by those connected to Baylor and it's leaders.  Most of those stories will never be known.

column1: In honor of #WomensHistoryMonth -- Who's a Baylor woman who's inspired you::: and why?
column3: Dr. Marlene Reed is a Professor in my Department::: Entrepreneurshi p. I love her! She is a go-getter::: in her 80â€™s::: still teaching::: traveling::: writing::: loves her students and Loves Jesus! She inspires me everyday!
column4: Tommy Lou Davis changed my life. She helped my to believe in myself and restore my self confidence I attribute much of my success in graduate school and business to the foundation she built for me. I canâ€™t speak highly enough of her!!ğŸ˜
column5: Ann Miller had a huge impact on me (as did her brother James Vardaman.) Mona Choucair was not a professor when I was there as sheâ€™s only a few years older than me but I have heard from so many the impact that she has on students. Truly a master teacher. And she has a pretty great sister Salwa Choucair Lanford::: my longtime close Baylor friend.
column6: Very fitting that Dr. Choucair is in this pic collage! Sheâ€™s amazing.
column7: Dr. Lynne Gackle::: servant of God::: humble leader::: grand mentor. She has inspired many through her words and actions. We love her!
column8: Professor Katherine Mueller aka Dr. Kay.  She was one of my BIC Professors::: I traveled to Thailand with her and she became my sociology major mentor.  I also remember that she would start off SOC 1305 by saying look to your left or right::: one of you may have your future spouse in the room.  She is right. That is how I met my husband. Weâ€™ve been together (including our time at Baylor) 22+ years.
column9: Dr. Martha Lou Scott helped me through many difficulties during my undergrad and grad school years in the 80â€™s. I was delighted that she was still at Baylor when my son came to Baylor. We wish her well on her retirement. Blessings!!
column10: Dr. Judith Lusk! She always was an encouraging professor and loved her strong work ethic and role modeling to her students!
column11: Dr. Anita Baker. She was such an amazing teacher and took a personal interest in her students. I ran into her in an airport about 5 years after I graduated and she remembered me and asked me to sit down and catch her up on what I was doing. Great example of how to build relationships with your students! â¤ï¸â¤ï¸
column12: Mrs. Pearlie Beverly! When I needed a kick in the rear::: she was there. When I needed understanding::: love and support::: she was there. I cannot ever thank her enough!!
column13: Ann Miller was a true inspiration. She was intelligent::: focused::: humorous and always encouraged striving to produce one's best product. She was one of my favorite women on the Baylor campus.....
column14: Professors Karon LeCompte::: Tracey Sulak::: Stephanie Gerow::: Jessica Akers::: Jenny Robins::: Jamie Van Eyck Beceiro::: and Lakia Scott are daily inspirations. Some of the smartest::: kindest women I know! Baylor is lucky to have them.  And my very favorite alum::: Shelley Davis. I truly could not live without her. She constantly inspires me to make friendships a top priority enjoy life to the fullest.
column15: Dr. Patricia Ward. Her grasp of American History was amazing and she presented in a captivating way. I always looked forward to her class.
column16: I grew up having lived next door to (Bob and) Ann Miller plus we were in church together at The First Baptist Church of Waco. She (and Bob) excelled in the classroom... there's no doubt about that!! Oh::: and also... she made delicious gingerbread men/women and I loved it when she'd call me over for one straight outta the oven! I'd go through the garage and on into the kitchen where it smelled sooo good! That was a real treat! Anyway::: just lots of very fond memories:)
column17: Mrs. Pearl Beverly! She was so kind::: caring::: and made such a positive impact. I was grateful to intern with her during my time at Baylor.
column18: Dr. Nesmith::: Dr. Cassidy::: Margaret Thomson::: & Dr. Gloer - all part of the school of education. These inspiring women helped me to get my first teaching job::: and taught me all I needed to know about being a great teacher. Iâ€™m so thankful to have been in their classes!
column19: Heather Hernandez is a Baylor woman who inspires me. I remember one day when we were students at Baylor::: she told me about her aspiration to one day own horses and use them to help people with special needs and other challenges. Heather has accomplished what most people only dream about - actually seeing her dream come to fruition. I am so proud of Heather and the work she does with equine therapy through her non-profit Reining Strength. Baylor should be proud of this distinguished alumna. ğŸ’šğŸ´ğŸ’›
column20: Jill Van Zee without a doubt! Amazing woman::: lover of Christ. I've always looked up to her as someone I can go to with anything work related or personal. I aspire to be just as amazing with our staff and faculty as she is. â¤ï¸
column21: My first math professor at Baylor. I had no idea at the time that I was privileged to have a living legend for a freshman math course.
column22: Ann Miller was a fascinating teacher of English. I had not really planned to be an English teacher until I took three of her classes. Great Baylor woman!
column23: Dr. Patricia Wallace was the most amazing history professor. Her lectures were amazing. Dr. Pat Sharp taught childrenâ€™s literature. Her class was also wonderful.
column24: Those who have taught my husband::: my sons::: or me::: or who worked alongside us in a way that impacted us: Kay Mueller Ann Miller Patricia Wallace Ann Karafa Rachel Moore  Tommye Lou Davis Lynn Gackle Rebecca Poe Hays Beth Allison Barr Lori Baker Regina Easley Young Martha Lou Scott
column25: I will always remember Betsy Vardaman and Charlene Spoede fondly. They always seemed invested in students well beyond the level required.
column26: Pearl Beverly continues to inspire the very best. I canâ€™t imagine my college years without her influence!!
column27: Dr Rena Bonem Baylor Geology professor. She was great teacher::: she cared about the students::: and she led great summer field trips (the way to learn geology is out in it). She came up in the ranks in geology when it was a manâ€™s field but that never stopped her.
column28: Edith Potter! She was my French professor for several classes. She was dedicated::: inspiring::: and personable. Sheâ€™s one of the reasons I decided to be a French teacher.
column29: Dr. Lynne Gackle and Dr. Deborah Williamson! They truly saved my life and my experience at Baylor wouldnâ€™t have been as amazing as it was without them!
column30: Aubin Francis Petersen for her gift of hospitality::: her passion for advocacy and affirmation of our LGBTQ+ friends::: and her belief that Jesus demonstrated that Godâ€™s love is for all. No one is excluded. Oh::: and for being my partner and soulmate and inspiration for all these years.
column31: Professor Ann Miller without a doubt. Wonderful human being::: teacher and friend. We actually have that picture of her hanging in our office with a note she wrote to my husband.
column32: DeAnna Toten Beard - an amazing advocate for both current and past theatre majors. So dang smart and so infectiously joyful about passing on knowledge to us. So happy to have the theatre department under her wing.
column33: I can never thank Pearl Beverly enough. She continues to make a positive impact on the lives of so many!
column34: Tommye Lou Vines Davis::: Andrea Dixon::: Alice Starr::: Hope Loomis::: Lori Wasserman Fogleman::: Cassy Burleson::: Juli Rosenbaum::: Tam Dunn::: Adrienne Conradt::: Lori Baker::: Paula Lea...the list goes on. I am thankful to so many Baylor women who led and continue to lead so fearlessly. Sic â€˜Em!!
column35: Our granddaughter a graduate of Baylor inspires us all the time. Sheâ€™s a Christian and a very smart young woman. ğŸ’•
column36: These women helped to pave a way for women that look like me. Forever thankful for their love and educating me on more than academics.  Dr. Peaches Henry Pearl Beverly Pamela Davis-Silmon Dr. Kaiâ€™iah James Rosalind Winn-Baty
column37: The only Baylor woman i Stan!
column38: Dr. Choucair!! She changed the trajectory of my degree and career. I loved seeing her around town... sheâ€™d always come up and say hi and loved getting to know her students! I made everyone I could take one of her classes!! ğŸ˜
column39: Ann Miller::: the most brilliant and the most charismatic woman ever::: she inspired generations of women including me.
column40: Dr. Lynne Gackle! She is the very best of Baylor! She is excellent at her craft::: full of wisdom::: and loves the Lord and seeks to point others to Him!
column41: Jumping on the Dr. Lynne Gackle fan girl train because she deserves all the love for being an incredible mentor and teacher! She inspired me to pursue choral conducting and helped me through the hardest part of my college career with patience and grace.
column42: Dr. Michaela Ritter!! She was a great professor::: but what I remember most was going to her telling her I might have to miss my final because my grandma had just died. I remember her saying â€œfamily firstâ€ & then she took the time to pray with me right then and there. ğŸ¥°
column43: Giving a shoutout to BIC for having amazing women professors and I'm sad I didn't get to have all them as professors. Dr. Nogalski and Dr. Glass were exceptional and I got to develop wonderful relationships with them. They helped me so much when I was thereâ™¥
column44: Dr. Pat Ward. She blended history like cream in coffee. I took every class she taught::: and then had the privilege of working for her my final year. Amazing!
column45: Dr Pat Sharpe; she taught me to love childrenâ€™s literature and encouraged me by telling me how excellent my writing was. That has obviously stuck with me for a lot of years!
column46: Dr. Lynne Gackle and Dr. Jillian Veiga Gusukuma for their unconditional love and support in the field of music.  Dr. Kathy Whipple and Dr. Brittany Perrine for cultivating my love and passion to be an SLP.
column47: Dr. Lynne Gackle! She is a huge inspiration to me and such an amazing educator.
column48: Amanda Slamcik Lassetter is the definition of resilience::: strength::: and pure love for her students. column49: Dr. Madalene Barnett taught many of us to become speech language pathologists. She was funny but required much of us. column50: I second Dr Beck...took Women in Religion in America with her and really opened my eyes!
column51: Helen Ann Shanley::: my flute teacher! She is the reason I attended Baylor and::: 30+ years later::: continues to be such an important role model for me in my performing and teaching! Iâ€™m grateful for her continued friendship! ğŸ’šğŸ’› ğŸµ Baylor University School of Music
column52: Drs. Doris DeLoach and Ann Shoemaker - both are absolute pillars for anyone who studied a woodwind instrument at Baylor in the past decade...
column53: Dr. Julie Holcomb is an incredible professor and is so supportive of her students! Everyone in our masters program was so fortunate to be able to learn from her ğŸ¥°
column54: Dr. Elizabeth Davis - hands down::: the best professor ever. Learned so much about accounting::: professionalism ::: and compassion from my time in her classes and being around her as Dean. Will never forget her influence in my life.
column55: My cousin. I always looked up to her as a child so when she went to Baylor I decided I would too. Graduated with my BSN in 2002 and love every minute of being a Baylor Bear! Alex Elder
column56: My daughter Maddie Doucet. â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸ Iâ€™ve never known anyone who has worked harder than this girl has to achieve her dreams. Sheâ€™s had some tough stuff to overcome but she did so with such strength and grace. At the age of seven years old::: Maddie decided she wanted to be a doctor. She graduated Baylor Cub Laude with a degree in biology and a minor in Spanish. She spent 2020 working on the front lines testing for Covid and working in an urgent care. This year she will start med school. As parents::: itâ€™s our job to teach our children::: but in my case::: itâ€™s my daughter who has taught me about strength::: dedication::: chasing your dreams and never giving up. She truly inspires me every day.
column57: Mia Moody-Ramirez ::: Lori Wrzesinski::: & Marnie Abrahams ! Amazing professors::: leaders::: mentors::: role-models & supporters during my time at Baylor & beyond! column58: My dear friend Daffy Tabor was a Baylor grad. She was a dear friend to me for many years and I miss her terribly. She used to say she graduated â€œLordy how comeâ€ from Baylor! She died several years ago and Iâ€™ll always miss her.
column59: Yes beautiful::: smart Aunt Laura! She raised 4 wonderful children and finished her education and worked. A woman before her time!
column60: Dr. Kayte Thomas has been an inspiration for me in several ways. Her passion for social justice and refugees provides a great example of the type of social worker I admire very much.
column61: My mother Martha Baker who taught basic skills and pediatric nursing for 25 years.
column62: Dr Choucair::: Dr Livingstone and Auntie Pearl are all pretty great but I think Cheryl Segura Gochis would have to be the best (no bias of course). Thankful for the way she leads and serves during some of the toughest times in this Universityâ€™s history (football::: I35 reconstruction::: Covid). column63: Dr. Lynne Gackle. Her leadership::: talent::: and total dedication to her choral music calling::: her students and Baylor through thick and thin has been an inspiration and example what is important in life::: people and oneâ€™s ability to help them. I am certain there are thousands around this nation who would second me in my sentiments. Baylor is fortunate to have such a person on their faculty!
column64: Dr. Patricia Hesterly Tolbert told me to apply to grad school. It wasn't on my radar or in my plan::: but she was so incredibly kind::: smart::: thoughtful and genuine that she literally changed the course of my life.
column65: Dr. Pooler and Dr. Ritter have made a huge impact on my learning as I go through the MSW program
column66: I had many magnificent professors at Baylor who are women. My work today has been directly influenced by all of them. Dr Patricia Wallace mastered the lecture as an instructional methodâ€”she remains one of the best. And her method of testing by extensive essay to argue a position served me well through my own PhD work. I had her for 12 hours in the same yearâ€”Survey of American History and American Foreign Policy. She honored me by asking me to be her grader::: but I needed to decline. She always had an open door and an ear. Professor Patricia Howard taught me first semester English and one of the sophomore coursesâ€”After Burns. Outstanding both in course material and off the cuff remarksâ€”she introduced me to the book Your God is Too Small by JB Phillips::: which remains relevant to me. Her side lecture on that book left an impression on a very narrow thinking 17 year old in 1981â€“it helped me start journeying away from provincial thinking. Professor Vickie Klaras taught a magnificent English Before Burns course that also left a great impression. They all enriched me. My greatest experiences at Baylor were in the classroom under professors and these were tops. Finally::: while I did not have Dr. Rosalie Beck in my doctoral workâ€”She wasnâ€™t graduate faculty until the end of my courseworkâ€”she was a reader on my dissertation and a very positive influence over the years.
column67: Linda McManness I admire your passion to educate others not only on the Spanish language but on the culture as well! I will always be grateful to have been taught by you in Denia!
column68: I worked for Madelynn Jones in the Registrarâ€™s office when I was a student. She was an amazing role model and left such a lasting impact â¤ï¸
column69: Pearl Beverly::: she was gem and every encounter at the SUB with her was a pleasant one.
column70: My friend Jo Beth Thornton Grubbs. Sheâ€™s an excellent teacher::: wife::: mother::: grandmother::: friend to many::: and an inspiring follower of Christ. You could ask for no better alumni!
column71: Lauren Mikeal Weber Melissa Engelland Johnson Meredith Sutton and Lisa Denman (wouldnâ€™t let me tag) exemplify what it means for strong::: talented women to cheer on other women. I am so lucky to have learned from your example â¤ï¸
column72: Dr. Judith Lusk::: who arrived at Baylor my sophomore year::: and transformed the fashion design/fashion merchandising department. And my mom::: Vicki Park::: who was a proud Baylor grad.
column73: Ann Miller was the best! She taught me so much more than just literature. Most influential professor to me during my time at Baylor::: and I was a biology major
column74: Jerrie Callen gave me a new love for literature and writing. I began my teaching career in the English classroom::: though I love grading less in health and PE now in year 30.
column75: Mona Mae Choucair is amazing!!! She sat in the lobby with me when I was a freshman and helped me write a paper! She continues to be a positive influence on Baylor youth.
column76: Ann Miller! She was passionate about English Lit and so relatable. I still remember her lectures and priceless side comments.
column77: Lisa Murphy from CL&L and all the restâ€” powerful kindness and powerful leadership wrapped up in care for students and for the community.
column78: Therese Ellis for her perseverance and pivoting when her original plan didnâ€™t work out and working so hard to achieve her goal of becoming a lawyer.
column79: Dr Susan Wallace and Professor Mariana Griggs neither is at Baylor anymore but they pioneered the forensics department at Baylor and made a huge impact on a select group of students who were part of that program when it exist. 15yrs later and Mariana is still one of my closest friends. ğŸ’•
column80: Dr. Vivienne Malone-Mayes. She was a long time friend of my family. Although Baylor refused to admit her as an undergraduate simply because she was black::: she persevered. Ironically::: although Baylor refused to admit her as a student::: Baylor ended up hiring her as its first black professor. column1: Just a year after BUâ€™s first graduating class::: Mary Gentry Kavanaugh became the first woman to earn a degree from Baylor University. #WomensHistoryMonth  WWW2.BAYLOR.EDU Meet Mary Gentry Kavanaugh::: Baylor Class of 1855 -- and BU's first female graduate
column3: BU â€˜ 78 Mary would have graduated from Baylor Female College of Baylor University at Independence::: Texas (1845-1886) As mentioned in the article::: â€œcollegeâ€ was different in the early days. Children attended school until about age eleven or twelve. Any schooling after that was â€œhigher educationâ€::: or college. Thatâ€™s why Mary entered school at age seven and graduated from the Female College of BU at age 16 in 1855. Baylor Female College ( present University of Mary Hardin Baylor) relocated to Belton after an administrative rift which took the male students and faculty to Waco in 1886.
column4: Another Baylor Connection (even if my paternal great grandmother was a Methodist): Andora Keesee::: who graduated from what would later be Southwestern University::: was the first woman to earn a university degree in Texas. Her grandson::: my dad::: Dr. Walstein Smith::: Jr. (1920-1998) taught business law and real estate for 41 years at Baylor. His Bachelors of Business Administration and his J.D. (both in 1941) were also from Baylor when he was only 21 years-old. He incidentally worked for a year as a McGregor soda jerk before he matriculated at Baylor at age 16. He was the second youngest graduate of Baylor Law School. His M.A. and Ph.D. were from the University of Texas. https:// texashistory.unt .edu/ark:/ 67531/ metapth30632/
column5: Was she ever awarded an actual degree::: or just a certificate of completion? Maybe Baylor can make that right? There were apparently a lot of female slaves who did the work at home that allowed Mary to attend school. They should also be recognized::: as a part of this history.
column6: She graduated in 1855! Thatâ€™s most excellent! It raises the question: If BU opened in 1846 why was itâ€™s first graduating class not until 1854???
column8: My grandmother was class of 1932 and I was class of 1999. Thank you Mary for paving the way!
column13: Opening the door::: for many others.

column1: "I want people to see the range of Black writers who were and are engaging in questions about individual and communal responses to race in America."  Celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth by reading some of the best of Black American literature:  WWW2.BAYLOR.EDU Interested in diving into Black literature? Check out this list from Baylor English profs
column3: I donâ€™t believe these are all available at the library... can we add these along with some additional titles to our actual library not just a public list?
column4: I read Toni Morrison's "Beloved" as part of my World Literature class with Dr:::. Ashvin Kini during the summer of 2020. It tells the story of a woman named Sethe who lives at a house called 24 on the outskirts of Cincinnati around nine or so years after the end of slavery and the Civil War. Sethe is in her middle thirties living with her eighteen-year-o ld daughter::: Denver::: named for Amy Denver::: a white girl who helped her escape. She and the others are continually haunted by the ghost of a child she had killed during her escape. The book is a fictionalized version of the true story of Margaret Garner::: who escaped to freedom only to kill her children rather than have them back home under slavery. From what I remember::: Garner was later put on trial for child endangerment and murder and sentenced to death. A short::: but interesting book. I liked Kiran Desai's "The Inheritance of Loss" more::: though.

Baylor's Board of Regents today officially accepted the final report of the Commission on Historic Campus Representations::: setting a path forward to developing an action plan based on the Commission's recommendations.  The full Commission report will be released by the end of March. First::: Baylor will hold three forums as part of the ongoing "Baylor Conversation Series" to discuss slavery in the U.S.::: slavery in Texas and among Texas Baptists::: and the Commission's findings & recommendations.  Upon acceptance of the Commission's report::: the Board charged the University Administration with developing a proposed action plan regarding the Commissionâ€™s recommendations.  At their quarterly meeting::: the Board also: * received updates on COVID-19 efforts::: #GiveLightBU::: and the Illuminate strategic plan; * expressed appreciation to Baylor Dining & Facilities staff for their efforts this week; and * announced a timeline for the upcoming Alumni-elected Regents election.  Details:  BAYLOR.EDU Baylor Board of Regents Accepts Independent Report from Commission on Historic Campus Representations
column3: Is history so fragile that removing idols will erase it? Do any of you genuinely believe history is being erased forever? I mean::: I can see how you'd be concerned given the erasure of entire native groups and much of their history. The whitewashing of African history and culture might be another example. Perhaps your nervousness is born of the deep understanding of how oppression works::: handed down through the generations. All lives matter::: this is absolutely true::: that's why black lives matter. By opposing the removal of statues of people who did not value human life::: some might say you are favoring one life over another. In your own words::: and by your actions::: suggesting only one side of history should be commemorated is indicative of the mindset that says the enslaved people hold no value to you::: only the person that owned them. What of my ancestors? My heritage? We are learning from our past::: I'm just wondering what lessons have some of you learned? Are we trying to take notes to repeat certain events::: only more successfully? Or are we learning as a means of prevention? My ancestors longed for freedom and each generation has fought for freedom and an equitable society. Seems some don't want to see those that look like me learn from those struggles? We are just to accept your careful study of oppression? Why? Does it bother you that even without idols planted everywhere::: people of color insist on being their ancestor's wildest dreams?
column4: I am appalled that Baylor is considering removing statues of founders. History is past. Learn from it. Don't try to change it. I am through with the changing apologetic response to people who are racists themselves. All lives matter period. Ask Jesus.
column5: Don't take down any statues. Don't give in to the mob. Learn from the past. Don't try to erase it.
column6: Grateful to this commission and to Baylor for taking beginning steps in this necessary work. I am looking forward to learning more through the three upcoming Zoom meetings.
column7: Dr. Ben Carson recently appealed to the American people to use common sense & our brains regarding the inequality issues that we see being incited today. He::: like me & others raised during the 50's &/or 60's::: have witnessed firsthand the real history which has taken place since a time when daily inequality & racial issues truly existed. Thankfully today::: great strides have been made in America regarding equality.  The movement to remove historical monuments which we suddenly see young people inciting today throughout the country is a newly learned::: skewed view.  ...Another Alinsky movement.  Use the common sense that God gave you. No one is perfect but::: the vast majority of people are good. Don't send America into a backward spiral by allowing yourself to accept & promote the skewed views being used to create division... in either direction.
column8: Prayers for a firm stand in the Lord. No matter what else::: we need to remain a university that upholds Jesus and the Word of God. â€œUnapologetical ly Christianâ€ is why we chose Baylor. Please resist the critical theory and moral relativism of this age.
column9: Iâ€™m very proud of Baylor and their decision to not only bring attention to these representations ::: but to also take action against them.
column10: The only constant in life is change and Baylor has changed a lot since I was in school there in the â€˜80s. When my first bear went there and I found out there were coed dorms::: I could not wrap my head around it. They have progressed in so many areas::: I am proud to see how far they have come and understand they have a loooong way to go to to offer equality to all students from varying backgrounds. However::: I also feel that we have to be careful judging people from the past with the standards from today. I think we can be honest about acknowledging the personal struggles and flaws of our founders without erasing their historical significance.
column11: Yes::: Jennifer Lacy::: history is that fragile::: and if it were not also so powerful::: the enemies of liberty and truth on the left would not be trying so hard to destroy it! Nothing we can do will change the fact that for many centuries your ancestors sold other human beings into slavery::: some of them to my ancestors. But the fact is that the ideals that drove Baylor's founders have been instrumental in creating a society that strives to honor and ensure the liberty and dignity of all humans. Those ideals have eliminated slavery and advanced human dignity everywhere they have prevailed. I want to preserve the statue of Judge Baylor not to honor the fact that he was a slaveholder::: but to honor his memory because he loved our Lord and Texas::: and that he wanted to serve them by establishing a university as a seat of Christian education.
column12: Did anyone see anything about removing statues or name-changing here? The official::: oft-told histories of Baylor are incomplete. The intent is not to erase history but to tell a more complete and accurate history. And by the way Critical Race Theory has been widely taught for 20 or more years. It has absolutely nothing to do with moral relativism. Baylor is about being a caring Christian community for ALL its student::: faculty and staff.
column13: This isnâ€™t about â€œerasing history.â€ Itâ€™s about acknowledging the harm that these historic representations cause. Itâ€™s about taking a critical look at the voices and experiences and perspectives that are amplified on Baylorâ€™s campus.

Baylor Family in Waco â€“ Waco Mayor Dillon Meek has asked us to spread the word:  As you are able::: please inspect your homes/facilities to ensure there are no water leaks. If there are leaks::: report them to 254-299-2489.  This measure will help us keep the Waco water system functioning.  Dillon Meek February 18::: 2021 at 10:43 AM Â·  URGENT:  PLEASE SHARE THIS::: TAG FOLKS::: AND GET OUT THE WORD! WE NEED TO FIND AND RESOLVE LEAKS THAT ARE OCCURRING ALL OVER THE CITY.  If you haven't been to your place of business or facility in the last several days::: please safely make arrangements for an inspection. Report any leaks you see to (254) 299-CITY (2489). We need to locate any and all leaks to preserve water. If your house or business has a leak::: turn off the water valve to your home or building. (If you can't find it::: please call us immediately and we will send someone to turn the water off at the meter.)  While we do not anticipate water completely being shut off::: we could have to go to a boil water notice (meaning water would not be safe to drink without boiling it) if leaks are not quickly resolved.  City personnel is safely driving around Waco tracking down leaks in all ways possible - please join us in this urgent need to resolve leaks.

column12: Hello all::: I'm the general manager at the baylor papa John's on 7th and Cleveland. I've heard some stories about the food situation on campus. I just wanted to let everyone know we aren't delivering at this time. However::: I'm looking at a location where I could set up in a parking lot and send someone over to sell pizzas at a discounted price. In the meantime we are only open for in-person carryout only. You can not call or order online. Due to high volumes we had to turn everything off. We mostly will only be open till 5pm. Get with your roommates and friends and make arrangements to get stocked up before 5pm. We are working very hard to service everyone during this winter wonderland. Thank you for your business and time. We appreciate everyone's understanding. Please share this information with anyone who maybe wondering if we're open.  Brittany

column3: I read a book written back in the kate 1780's that was talking about a first hand account of the Native Americans.  Well::: in the book the Arthur is describing the Greek statue like physique of the Indians.  I remember the next paragraph attributes their physique and strength to their diet of fish::: lean meats::: and roots.  He then compares the typical English diet of breads and alcohol to why the English where so fat and weak compared to these new people who look like the Greek gladiator statues. column1: STUDENTS: We've got more details for you on the weekly COVID-19 testing that will take place this semester: http://bit.ly/2LNb05q  The good news? Our health experts believe this testing will increase our chances of hosting more in-person events and activities this spring.  Our goal is to make weekly testing as easy & convenient as possible::: via regular appointments & multiple testing locations. Each student has been pre-assigned a weekly testing day::: time & location. If that time doesn't work::: you can select a new time by 8 a.m. on Jan. 18.  If you miss your regular testing appointment for the week::: you don't need to reschedule; just walk in for an appointment at your designated testing location. Just make sure you make up the appointment during the same week.  If you have tested positive for COVID-19 within the last 90 days::: you are currently exempted from testing until that 90 days expires. You will receive a follow-up email with the date to begin weekly testing.  (Faculty/Staff: Your weekly testing procedure is slightly different; please see details and FAQs here: http://bit.ly/3ssQcAX)  We understand that testing may be an inconvenience::: but we believe it will allow us to best manage any COVID-19 outbreaks -\-\ and provide additional opportunities for on-campus events::: meetings & activities.  Thanks for understanding as we work together to #SicCOVID!

column1: LADY HEALTH UPDATE: Judge Lady::: one of our two beloved American black bears::: is progressing to the next phase of her recovery and rehabilitation from a successful operation to remove a cyst that developed around her spinal column.  Lady has steadily progressed through the first phases of recovery::: primarily in her personal living space within the Williams Bear Habitat. Next is a gradual return to the Habitat's public portion. Public access will be closed initially as Lady returns to the Habitat.  Visitors may notice irregular hair growth along her spine::: as her fur continues to grow back after surgery. Although her mobility has improved::: visitors may also notice a slight catch in her gait. Her caregiver team continues to monitor her progress.  â€œLady has made an amazing recovery:::â€ says Dr. Sharman Hoppes::: exotic animal veterinarian from Texas Avian & Exotic Hospital and professor emerita in zoological medicine at Texas A&M. â€œItâ€™s so exciting to get her back into her outdoor enclosure.â€  Details:  BAYLOR.EDU Baylor Bear Mascot Lady Progressing to Next Phase of Recovery and Rehabilitation Plan

column3: I could see the highway from my dorm - Brooks - Enjoyed going down to the Brazos River and sometimes walking into town. Nice Memories...
column4: One of the young men I dated at Baylor lived in Brooks Hall and he worked the switchboard at that dorm. He said he was always tempted to answer::: â€œBrooks Hall. Who in the hall do you want?!â€ His dad had lived in Brooks::: too. His dad and some buddies got in trouble for writing their names on a door on the top floorâ€”thinking no one would see it there near the attic. Their punishment was to make a new door. After it was finished to the satisfaction of the administration::: they were allowed to sign their work! So::: on the first Homecoming when his dad visited::: his dad told the tale and showed his work to his son. (Both father and son::: as far as I know::: turned out just fine!) Brooks seems to have been rowdy in those days. My uncle::: who must have been at BU about the same time as my friendâ€™s dad::: also stayed in Brooks. He said that some of the athletes were giving him grief (probably wanting him to do their work since he was a near genius.) The big bullies had threatened him. So::: he told his best friend from home (McGregor) about it. They were neighborhood friends and had grown up together. The friend was also an athlete and a couple of levels ahead. He gathered some of his friends and they hid in a large cedar tree next to the dorm. When the bully and his buddy came byâ€”ready to whip my uncleâ€”the other guys appeared from the tree. The bullies had the good sense to runâ€”and to stay away from my uncle from then on! I donâ€™t know about the bullies::: but my uncle and his friends went on to have remarkably successful lives and careers.

column1: STUDENTS: We can't wait to have you back on campus -- and neither can Coach Drew!

ICYMI -\-\ President Livingstone's email today includes multiple reminders and updates about COVID-19 testing at Baylor this spring.  * Spring semester classes are still expected to begin as scheduled on Tuesday::: Jan. 19.  * All students::: faculty & staff are required to submit a negative COVID-19 test prior to returning to Waco. The Everlywell test kit ordering deadline for students is this Saturday.  * Following the latest recommendations for universities::: all BU students::: faculty & staff will undergo required weekly COVID-19 testing this spring::: as we hope to unlock additional normalcy as the semester progresses. Additional details will follow in the weeks ahead.  * Facemasks & proper social distancing will again be required on campus this spring -\-\ important safeguards at this critical stage of the pandemic.  * In accordance with new CDC guidance::: we have reduced the length of quarantine for exposed individuals from 14 days to 10 days.  * BU has received 300 doses of the Moderna vaccine so far; they are being given to Phase 1A individuals (including medical personnel::: emergency responders::: & nursing faculty/staff & students). We are developing plans for Phase 1B::: provided we obtain additional doses.  * As campus activity returns::: we anticipate a similar situation to fall::: when we saw an initial spike in cases. We are confident in our protection::: mitigation & response measures for a successful spring. We ask for your cooperation and support in keeping our Family First.  * Provided that our COVID-19 case numbers are low and compliance with health measures is strong::: we are planning to provide students a â€œwellness dayâ€ in which there will be no classes on Tuesday::: March 9 (March 10 for the Nursing School).  Read President Livingstone's email for more information:  BAYLOR.EDU Presidential Perspective - January 7::: 2021

Our thoughts & prayers are with the family & friends of longtime Baylor philosophy professor Stuart Rosenbaum following his passing.  Dr. Rosenbaum (BA '65) taught at Baylor for nearly 40 years until his retirement in 2019::: serving many years as director of the philosophy graduate program and twice earning Baylor's Outstanding Faculty Member Award: http://bit.ly/35bGYiq

column1: STUDENTS: Just like this fall::: a negative COVID-19 test will be required before you return to Waco in January.  Details â¡ï¸ http://bit.ly/2LGMSBx  Good news: The pre-semester testing process has improved significantly since the fall. Our testing partner::: Everlywell::: has created a Baylor-specific portal that will allow you to easily order your test kit directly and have it sent to your preferred address. Pre-arrival & regular testing during the semester will open up the potential to host more in-person activities in the spring.  Please order your test kit NOW so you will have it on hand -\-\ BUT wait to collect your specimen until 3-5 days before your return to Waco in January. Then::: send it back on the same day of collection to Everlywell via UPS.  Students not attending classes on the Waco campus will receive testing instructions directly from their specific school or program leadership.  Questions? Check out the information in the link above; if your question isn't answered there::: use the contact info here: http://bit.ly/2LGMSBx  (Faculty/Staff: Your COVID-19 testing procedure is a little different; please follow the instructions found here: http://bit.ly/34gKSWU)  Thank you for your cooperation::: and we look forward to seeing everyone back on campus in the spring! #SicCOVID

This fall::: statues honoring Baylor alumni Jack Lummus & John Kane -- believed to be the only pair of student-athletes at any university to have been awarded the Medal of Honor -- will go up outside McLane Stadium.  Kane played football & basketball at Baylor before leading a daring air raid against the Nazis in 1943: http://bit.ly/2OofJX9  Lummus played three sports at BU (plus a year in the NFL) before giving his life at Iwo Jima: http://bit.ly/3cAAzj3  Thank you to Haag (BBA â€™88) & Millette Sherman of Houston for providing funding & leadership for the creation of these statues::: which are nearing completion and expected to be installed at McLane Stadium in late November.  We will celebrate this moment with our generous donors at the Nov. 28 football game. ALL CLEAR: The gas leak near the 8th street parking garage has been resolved. It is safe to return to normal operations.  -----  [Original post::: 10:38 a.m.] BAYLOR ALERT: The Waco Fire Department is currently responding to a gas leak near the 8th street parking garage.  Avoid the area and do not start your vehicle inside the parking garage. Further information to follow.  [11:23 a.m. update:] The Waco Fire Department continues to respond to a gas leak near the 8th Street Parking Garage. Please avoid the area and do not attempt to start your vehicle if parked in the 8th Street Parking Garage. More information to follow.]  [12:01 p.m. update:] Atmos Energy crews are making repairs to the gas leak near the 8th street parking garage. The situation is currently stabilized. Please continue to avoid the area. The 8th street parking garage continues to be affected. More information will be available as there are updates.

column20: Kudos to Baylor for their continued diligent efforts to make the best of the semester during this pandemic. I admire Baylor's bold initiative to carefully open their campus this semester. Others have not done so.  Similar to other college game cancellations::: it is indeed sad this last minute game also had to be called off. But::: CoVid safety measures are identified & precautions are taken throughout all college systems for a reason.  The reality is that there are times when life becomes disruptive from our plans & dreams. My father was 17 when he enlisted in WWII as did many other students at the time including some from Baylor (such as Dave Campbell & Weldon Bigony for example). For us today::: it's CoVid causing the disruption in our daily lives. I don't know about you but::: I prefer a CoVid life disruption over a World War life disruption at this point.  Choose to be patient::: considerate::: supportive::: & respectful during this unprecedented time. We sometimes don't understand the sincere severity of a situation ... until it happens to us or someone we love.  Condolences to the family of Dr. Adeline Fagan.  https:// www.houstonchron icle.com/news/ houston-texas/ houston/amp/ Young-Houston-do ctor-dies-after -fighting-for-h er-15581069.php

column37: Glad I graduated before my school lost its backbone. Someone call prospective presidents::: when it gets found
column40: I understand Baylor having to follow the guidelines set by the Big 12::: but whatever group is setting those guidelines needs to get a clue. Contact tracing as a reason to cancel a game is ridiculous!! If any of those football players went to a class::: bought a cup of coffee::: held a door open for another student::: etc::: they we probably in contact with someone with covid. So will they contact trace those who were in the classroom before them::: served them the coffee::: or held the door for the previous person?  I think if the colleges cannot get it together::: they will see many students returning to their hometowns and taking classes at community colleges until this blows over.  You cannot take away every college experience from the students::: regardless of the covid situation. We are all frustrated::: but the kids just keep getting more and more taken away from them each day. They can't make friends at school::: they can't socialize at all::: they can't see the smile of another student::: and they can't enjoy typical college experiences such as a football game.  I hope Baylor is actively pushing for a threshold change with the Big 12 ASAP so our students can at least have some kind of college experience. I think someone needs to take into consideration how depressed these students are getting with each let down. If things do not change quickly::: severe depression among the students will become more of a health concern than covid.  If I have to tell my kids "everyone is in the same boat" again I think they will lose it. They are in the same boat and that boat is sinking! Football seems trivial but it is a brief distraction from the disappointments the students face daily. Let them play ball and let the students get in the stadium! Fight for that Baylor. Fight for your students!
column43: Better safe than sorry! A game is a game that can be rescheduled. A life cannot.

Shoot::: most of our kids are mostly online and no one is paying they to go to college::: quite the opposite.
